title: Post-Lobectomy Patient with Persistent Chest and Shoulder Pain
clinical_history: A 45-year-old male, who recently underwent a left upper lobectomy due to lung cancer, presents with complaints of persistent chest and shoulder pain. The surgery was performed 6 weeks ago, and the patient reports that the pain started shortly after the surgery. The pain is described as a constant ache in the chest and shoulder region, with occasional sharp pains when taking deep breaths or coughing.

nprs.affected_area: chest wall, specifically over the surgical site and left shoulder

aggrevating_factors: coughing, deep breathing, movement of the left arm, especially abduction and external rotation, prolonged lying on the left side
picture: 24-hour pain profile: pain is constant but varies in intensity; worse in the morning and evening, with some relief in between
easing_factors: position changes, sitting or standing upright, application of heat to the affected area
past_history: history of smoking (20 pack-years), hypertension, hyperlipidemia
medical_history: lung cancer, stage I, underwent left upper lobectomy 6 weeks ago
medications: acetaminophen 650mg q4-6h prn for pain, ondansetron 4mg q4-6h prn for nausea
personal_history: married, two children, works as an engineer, recently retired
imaging: post-operative chest X-ray and CT scan showing expected changes after lobectomy, no signs of complications
